description: Hanoi's largest freshwater lake at 5.3 km² with a 17-kilometer shoreline, located northwest of the city center. Originally part of the Red River, West Lake has existed since the Hung King period and served as a royal retreat during Ly-Tran dynasties. Surrounded by ancient pagodas, temples, and modern amenities, it's called Hanoi's Modern Quarter, offering a serene escape from urban chaos.
highlights: Tran Quoc Pagoda - Vietnam's oldest pagoda from 6th century on lake islet
Quan Thanh Temple - built during Ly Dynasty (1010-1225) to protect the city
Phu Tay Ho Pagoda and Kim Lien Pagoda
22 national heritage sites and 7 municipal heritage sites around lake
West Lake Water Park inspired by Santorini, Greece
West Lake Flower Valley with seasonal blooms near Dam Tri Lotus Pond
SUP rowing and swan boating activities
17km shoreline perfect for walking and cycling
Stunning sunset views over the water
Lush greenery, elegant villas, and floating restaurants
tips: Best season: October-April (dry season) for cooler weather
Ideal months: August-October according to tourist experience
Best time of day: late afternoon and evening for sunset and socializing
Walking/cycling highly recommended - bike rental 40,000-50,000 VND for 3 hours
Don't swim in the lake - pollution and bacterial risk
Use safe swimming pools available around the lake instead
Located 22km from Noi Bai Airport, 7km from Hanoi Railway Station
Visit Tran Quoc Pagoda at sunset for best photos
Explore nearby temples for cultural and religious heritage
Enjoy local cafés and restaurants with lake views
vibe: Tranquil and expansive, West Lake offers a peaceful retreat where ancient spirituality meets modern leisure. At sunset, the water transforms into liquid gold while pagodas cast long shadows. Locals cycle the shoreline, couples stroll hand-in-hand, and the buzz of the city fades into gentle waves. It's where Hanoi breathes - a 17-kilometer embrace of calm that reminds visitors why this lake has captivated emperors and commoners for over a millennium.
